channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Erdogan Curbs Criticism of Trump, Seeking Warmer Relationship
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey delivering a speech in Ankara last month. He sees President Trump’s rise as a chance to reset relations with the United States.
item.description: President Recep Tayipp Erdogan of Turkey even held his tongue on President Trump’s travel ban, hoping that Mr. Trump would rewrite policy on Syria, Kurds and an exiled provocateur.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY and TIM ARANGO

item.title: For Kushner, Israel Policy May Be Shaped by the Personal
item.media:description: Jared Kushner, second from left, with his wife, Ivanka Trump, and Stephen K. Bannon, the president’s chief adviser, at the White House on Friday for a visit by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan.
item.description: Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law, has a profound connection to Israel. When he meets with the country’s prime minister on Wednesday, it will be a gathering influenced by old encounters and shared experiences.
item.dc:creator: JODI KANTOR

item.title: Syria’s Assad Sends Signals to Trump in Interview
item.media:description: Residents walked through the destruction in eastern Aleppo last month, after it was brought back under the control of government forces.
item.description: The Syrian president suggested he could foresee cooperation with the Trump administration. He also held himself blameless for the six-year-old war.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: As Ties With U.S. Cool, Europeans Look to Forge Other Alliances
item.media:description: Federica Mogherini, the European Union’s foreign minister, met with Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson at the State Department on Thursday in Washington.
item.description: “Europeans will be more transactional, and we will base our approach on our interests,” a top European Union official said while in Washington.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Ljubisa Beara, Who Oversaw Massacre at Srebrenica, Dies at 77
item.media:description: Col. Ljubisa Beara was tried and convicted of war crimes at The Hague for his role in the 1995 mass killings of thousands of Muslims at Srebrenica.
item.description: Colonel Beara, a Bosnian Serb military officer, was serving a life sentence for his part in the murders of up to 8,000 Muslim men and boys over a five-day period in 1995.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Breaking Up the Family as a Way to Break Up the Mob
item.media:description: Roberto Di Bella thinks that severing familial links restores the possibility of a normal life to the children of mob families.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: An Italian magistrate separates children from their mob families and moves them elsewhere in Italy to interrupt a generational cycle of criminality.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: NATO Checking Claim that U.S. Airstrikes Killed 22 Afghan Civilians
item.media:description: Afghan police during an operation against Taliban militants in the Sangin district of Afghanistan’s Helmand province in January.
item.description: Elders from the Sangin district have said that multiple American airstrikes early Friday killed at least 22 civilians, including several women and children.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and TAIMOOR SHAH
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Chinese-Indonesian Governor’s Struggles Worry Some in His Ethnic Group
item.media:description: Chinese-Indonesians in Jakarta. Their ethnic group, which makes up 1 to 4 percent of Indonesia’s population, has a long history of being persecuted.
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.description: Some fear that Basuki Purnama’s run for Jakarta governor will create a backlash against Chinese-Indonesians, who have a long history of being persecuted.
item.dc:creator: JON EMONT

item.title: Mexican Government Rejects Findings of Misconduct in Missing Students Case
item.media:description: Relatives of missing students and other protesters gathered in Guadalajara, Mexico, on Sept. 26, 2016, to commemorate the second anniversary of the students’ disappearance.
item.description: An original review described serious wrongdoing by investigators, but a new report wiped clean the most damning violations.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Rich ‘Apprentice’ Host in Politics? But This Mayor Says He’s No Trump
item.media:description: Mayor João Doria of São Paulo, Brazil, center in white cap, helped plant a tree in the Vila Carrão neighborhood on Sunday. He took office in January.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Using attention-grabbing tactics, João Doria, the new mayor of São Paulo, Brazil, has cast himself as an outsider prepared to shake up the political scene.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: African Nations Increasingly Silence Internet to Stem Protests
item.media:description: People waiting to vote in the presidential election outside a polling station in Banjul, Gambia, in December. Government officials said security concerns prompted internet services to be shut off and international cellphone calls to be blocked.
item.description: Governments facing opposition in sub-Saharan Africa call internet blackouts a security measure, but crippled communications are taking a toll on their economies.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and FRANCOIS ESSOMBA

item.title: French Farmer Who Aided Migrants Is Given Suspended Fine
item.description: Cédric Herrou, 37, has become something of a hero for challenging the official policy of rounding up those who cross the border illegally.
item.dc:creator: BENOÎT MORENNE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Losing Hope in U.S., Migrants Make Icy Crossing to Canada
item.media:description: The road to asylum. The highway from Emerson, Canada, to Winnipeg, where many migrants go to seek refugee status.
item.media:credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
item.description: They fled their home countries seeking safety. Now, with President Trump in the White House, some are making the dangerous passage to Canada.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE PORTER, DAN LEVIN and IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Rockets Hit Baghdad's Green Zone After Protests Turn Violent
item.description: Two rockets landed in Baghdad's highly fortified Green Zone on Saturday night following clashes at anti-government protests that left five dead, according to Iraqi security and hospital officials.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Strong Quake Strikes Southern Philippines, Killing at Least 6
item.media:description: An injured woman was accompanied by family members at a hospital in Surigao on Saturday.
item.description: A temblor that was measured at magnitude 6.7 rattled the city of Surigao late Friday, leaving scores injured and many residents in the dark.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR
item.category: Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology

item.title: Canada Today: An Isolated Lake and a Welcome Mat for Refugees
item.media:description: The northern lights illuminated the sky above the Grey Goose Lodge, the only hotel and restaurant in the village of Deline, Northwest Territories.
item.media:credit: Christopher Miller for The New York Times
item.description: A remote community aims to become a tourist destination, a vast photo archive unearths forgotten memories, and what to watch on Netflix in Canada.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: U.S. Blocks Palestinian Ex-Premier From Senior U.N. Post
item.description: The move was intended to signal American support for Israel and its defense of the position that there is no Palestinian state.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: News Analysis: Trump Foreign Policy Quickly Loses Its Sharp Edge
item.description: He is proving to be less of a radical than either his campaign statements or his tempestuous early phone calls with foreign leaders would suggest.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Trilobites: Long Before Making Enigmatic Earthworks, People Reshaped Brazil’s Rain Forest
item.media:description: New research suggests people were sustainably managing the Amazon rain forest much earlier than was previously thought.
item.description: New research finds that humans were sustainably managing the landscape, perhaps thousands of years before they were carving intricate geoglyphs into the earth.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

item.title: As Fighting Escalates in Ukraine, Attention Focuses on Donald Trump
item.media:description: Relatives and friends of Elena Volkova, a victim of shelling, at her funeral this week in Avdiivka, Ukraine.
item.description: The lack of a clear position on the conflict by the president has bewildered officials on both sides of the war, particularly in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

item.title: A Video, a Wheelchair, a Suitcase: Mystery of Vanished Tycoon Deepens
item.media:description: Xiao Jianhua in a park in Beijing in an undated photograph. The Chinese billionaire disappeared from the Four Seasons Hotel in Hong Kong last month and is believed to be in police custody in mainland China.
item.description: Security footage from the Four Seasons in Hong Kong where Xiao Jianhua lived is said to show him being taken away by about half a dozen unidentified men.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Where Camels Race and Win Beauty Contests
item.media:description: The traditional camel race during the Sultan Bin Zayed Heritage Festival, held at the Sweihan racecourse on the outskirts of Abu Dhabi.
item.description: An annual festival celebrating the camel kicked off near Abu Dhabi, with camel races and beauty contests.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: A Rare Survivor of a Philippine Drug Raid Takes the Police to Court
item.media:description: Maria Belen Daa, 61, with a photo of her son Marcelo, 31, in the Philippines last week. He was shot along with four others by the police, who raided his home looking for drugs last August.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: The survivor has provided a chilling account that challenges the government’s assertion that those killed in the antidrug campaign were shot by the police in self-defense.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: German Comedian Is Told Not to Repeat Lewd Lines About Erdogan
item.media:description: A German court has upheld a ruling barring the comedian Jan Böhmermann from repeating 18 of the 24 lines of his lewd poem satirizing Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.description: A civil court has ruled against Jan Böhmermann, who caused an uproar with his poem about Turkey’s president, though a criminal case was dropped.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Trump Adopts a Harder Line on Israeli Settlements
item.media:description: The Jewish settlement Ma’ale Adumim, in the West Bank.
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.description: The president told an Israeli newspaper that settlements “don’t help the process” and indicated he was rethinking moving the U.S. embassy to Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: In Welcoming Shinzo Abe, Trump Affirms U.S. Commitment to Defending Japan
item.description: An elaborate work-and-play visit is intended to showcase the president’s warm rapport with the leader of a central player in Asia.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and PETER BAKER

item.title: Hong Kong Subway Fire Injures at Least 17 People
item.description: The police said a man whom they identified only as a 60-year-old with the surname Cheung admitted starting the blaze and was charged with suspicion of arson.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG

item.title: Trump, Changing Course on Taiwan, Gives China an Upper Hand
item.media:description: President Trump boarding Air Force One in Florida on Sunday. Mr. Trump’s reversal on Taiwan could mean a tougher negotiating position in Beijing on trade, North Korea and other issues.
item.description: In pledging to honor the “One China” policy, the president may have averted confrontation with Beijing, but some said he also sullied his reputation there.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Iran Celebrates Its Revolution, and Thanks Some Americans
item.media:description: Students waved the Iranian flag during a rally in Tehran on Friday to celebrate the anniversary of the 1979 Islamic Revolution.
item.description: The National Day celebration seemed calculated to avoid further inciting President Trump, who has lashed out against the Islamic republic.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Four in France, Including 16-Year-Old Girl, Are Held in Bomb Plot
item.media:description: The police patroled the streets in Marseillan, which is southwest of Montpellier, France, on Friday. Four people were arrested by the antiterrorism police in Montpellier on suspicion of planning an attack.
item.description: The authorities “do not know where nor how” the suspects arrested near Montpellier had planned to carry out an “imminent” attack.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Steve Bannon Cited Italian Thinker Who Inspired Fascists
item.media:description: Stephen K. Bannon referred to the Italian philosopher Julius Evola in a Vatican speech in 2014.
item.description: Julius Evola was a darling of Italian Fascists and has caught on in the far-right circles Stephen K. Bannon nurtured at Breitbart News and harnessed for President Trump.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: ‘We Want a Better Life in a Better Country’
item.description: Elena Filip is one of tens of thousands of Romanians who have taken to the icy, cold streets of Bucharest to demand government accountability.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA and YARA BISHARA

item.title: Hundreds of Pilot Whales Die After Beaching in New Zealand
item.media:description: Volunteers trying to keep alive some of the pilot whales beached at the northern tip of New Zealand’s South Island on Friday. Officials said it was one of the country’s largest whale strandings.
item.description: Rescuers tried to send the whales back out to sea, but at least 250 died in what officials called one of the worst whale strandings in New Zealand’s history.
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Dutch Get Creative to Solve a Prison Problem: Too Many Empty Cells
item.media:description: De Koepel prison in Haarlem, the Netherlands, which recently housed migrants.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: In a nation where about a third of cells sit empty, the Netherlands has rented some to other governments, and it has turned some jails into refugee shelters.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Feeling ‘Pressure All the Time’ on Europe’s Treadmill of Temporary Work
item.media:description: Cristian Meiler is fluent in five languages and has a degree in hotel management. Despite decades of experience, he never managed to land a prized full-time job.
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.description: In the European Union, more than half the new jobs since 2010 have been through temporary contracts, creating more workers seeking full-time employment.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: Opinion: What We’re Fighting For
item.media:description: United States Army soldiers transported Iraqi detainees captured during Operation Steel Curtain in 2005.
item.description: Our acts of moral courage defend America as surely as any act of violence.
item.dc:creator: PHIL KLAY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: France, Without a Struggle, Is at a Loss
item.media:description: In Chartres, France, people holding blackboards showing the most important election issues for them, including health, peace, education and unity.
item.description: The country is now bereft of the two conflicts that long defined its politics: the Cold War and the workers’ movement.
item.dc:creator: MICHEL WIEVIORKA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: La France, perdue sans grand débat intérieur
item.media:description: Des Français à Chartres avec des tableaux indiquant leurs préoccupations principales dans l’élection présidentielle.
item.description: Le pays est en crise parce qu’il est orphelin des conflits qui ont longtemps défini sa vie politique: la guerre froide et le mouvement travailliste.
item.dc:creator: MICHEL WIEVIORKA
